content.description: SDS go up using only the 4 prominent slopers, mantle out.
SDS at shelf, traverse left and top out.
content.location: low, left side under the roof

content.description:
(If I'm wrong about any part of this, somebody please let me know!) 

  The original problem was a slight variation of the version now, the reason being that a hold broke off. Either way, this problem is really fun. Start matched on a horizontal jug, good crimp on the ceiling, then big move out to slopers on the lip of the roof--throw a heel, hit a slopey crimp to stop the swing w/ your left hand then mantle. Crux is hitting the slopey crimp.
content.protection: WATCH THE SWING, and rolling down the hill. A couple of pads and a couple of spotters: Your landing area is determined by how far off you swing on the crux move.
content.location: Middle of the lost roof boulder, the easy V2 problem on the left is, well I don't know if there is a name for the problem as I haven't found it documented in any published guide, nor has anyone ever given a name to it, so I call it "Lost Roof Jr."

content.description:
Cool little problem to see what the Lost Roof Problem is going to be like. I haven't found this problem documented anywhere, or a name be given to it--if anyone knows any other info regarding this please let me know!

 Really fun to practice footwork for roofs, you can get really creative on this one.

youtube.com/watch?v=6Bm__wX…
content.location: On the very left of the Lost Roof boulder. Starts same as the Lost Roof Problem (V4) but it trends left instead of going straight out.

content.description: Start matched low on knobbly edge with poor feet. Long move left to sloper, then right to sidepull. For this variation, the jug shelf is off.
content.location: to the left of Amy's Problem.

content.description:
Sit start left hand on knob and right hand on seam. Lock off with your right hand and grab edge. Match hands on the break. Get your foot on the knob, then go for the sidepull. Top out.

 Link to Beta: youtube.com/watch?v=jEb4WH_…

 Credit: Geoffrey Collawn Climber: Carson Taylor
Start on two small crimps and bad foot. Move up/left to small holds and angular slopers. Top out easily on arete.
content.location: Leftmost problem on the difficult-looking short overhang boulder on the left on your way to the lost roof.

content.description: Large, over hanging bouder with a handful of routes.
